title: Not sure why you need this app

content.text: I downloaded this app after seeing the editor pick and some reviews. After using it, I’m not sure why you would need it. It does not do anything further than Health. It’s less than the same health matrix. It seems to be the same thing as any other “health” app with cartoons. I guess it just didn’t do anything for me.

content.text:
The app appears to be decent with a good summary of information the phone and watch collect. The nutrition articles should be taken with a grain of salt. 

I took points off for their high-pressure sales tactics. I felt as if I was at an auto dealer being asked “what can I do to get you in a car today.”

I subscribed to the app, checked it out, and the. Cancelled my subscription. It’s not worth the black-Friday sales price.

Since I cancelled my subscription, the app has thrown up a “Prolong your Subscription” view and it doesn’t go away! (There was an “X” button but tapping did nothing.)

Time to ask for a refund.

content.text:
I subscribed to Gentler Streak for a year and really enjoyed some of the data. I did end up letting the subscription expire because I feel I have a better handle on my own training load now. On the positive, the app is well designed and I do feel like it was pretty decent at knowing when I needed to work vs rest, especially at first. However, once I got in a routine of regular workouts, it kept telling me to work harder to maintain my streak. Doing 30-60 minutes of strength training 3-4x per week and walking a lot seems like it should be plenty to keep me fit, but once Gentler Streak adapted to that routine, it started pushing me to do more and more in a way that felt unsustainable. 

I just returned from a 10-day trip to Europe, where we walked minimum 20K steps a day. I know the point of the app is to add more than just apple’s rings, but throughout that entire trip, the messages kept telling me to work out more and eventually “lost” my streak. I don’t mind that of course, but it’s wild that it can’t consider that I was walking 10 miles a day. 

I also think it’s absurd that period tracking isn’t included in the free version. Feels like holding back an extra feature for 50% of the users.

content.text: I have dysautonomia exacerbated by long Covid and I’ve been finding this app incredibly helpful for slowly building stamina and feeling better about taking extremely crucial rest days. After a few months I’ve gone from logging a couple minutes of walking or chores to logging hours of hiking and aerobics. Your mileage may vary, but this is one of the most accessible (and gentlest) apps out there.

content.text:
The app has a great looking UI and the functionality is exactly what I was looking to ensure that I am pushing the right amount during my trainings.
However it has 2 major flows that really really bother me.

1. The app does not sync on Strava or any other major "social fitness" platform. In 2024 this is really unacceptable. Everyone is connected and we like to maintain the social pressure as part of our motivation for working out. Just this flaw will translate in me not using Gentle Streak on the apple watch to track the runs, meaning that I am not able to use the great "body battery" indicator... 

2. The app is awesome to give you information on what to do today. It does not provide you with an upcoming plan for the week/month. That would be great to prepare properly and, if needed, organize the agenda accordingly. We are all busy and the possibility to prepare an adjustable plan will be more than welcome.

There are pros and cons in every app, but these 2 items (particularly #1) are so annoying that I wonder if I should maintain the subscription....

This app seems like it's a stellar fitness app with how it encourages breaks and not overexerting, as opposed to the past few fitness apps I tried that seem to think that missing 1 calorie of my goal means I should run a triple marathon the next day. 

But every time I do a workout and adjust my RPE, the Activity Path on my phone and watch desync. It takes multiple reinstalls and restarts of my watch to fix this. Fixing an app's buggy behavior should not be part of my fitness routine!

title: What about all of my other activity?

content.text:
I love this app and I am a long time subscriber, but it misses a huge part of my physical activity.

As I’ve seen in other reviews and in a support request, the developers dismiss the idea of using the data collected in Apple’s “Move” and “Exercise” rings. Only tracked workouts are taken into account.

The app uses the Training Impulse (TRIMP) method to quantify the training load and stress placed on an athlete's body during exercise with the (admittedly) more accurate workout data.

However, ignoring all of the other physical activity that we do means that when we have an above average day of non-workout activity, the app’s recommendation is no different and it asks us to push too hard during our workouts.

The developers dig their heels in over not being able to use the less accurate non-workout data to determine the toll that this activity has on our bodies, but they already use: sleeping heart rate, sleep duration, wrist temperature, heart rate variability, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation to estimate our overall wellbeing. These don’t fit anywhere in the TRIMP formula and are imperfect data that creates an imperfect estimate.

I appreciate the developers’ goal of using a science and data backed approach to be sure that their app serves and protects us. I hope that they can find a way to bring the same rigor to expand the capability of the app to bring non-workout activity into the fold to provide a better picture of our workouts, overall activity, and recovery.

content.text:
I was hopeful this would track steps in real time vs. the health app that only updates periodically. I’m glad I read the reviews before purchasing the annual service. 

I get that they can’t track the impact to our bodies, but some of us use steps to track our movement in the day just in general and have other things we participate in that require steps tracking. 

It’s a shortcoming of this app to not have something as simple as a daily step count.

I’ll update the stars for this app as I use it more.

content.text:
The Activity Path is awesome. It considers all the data I’m shoving into Apple Heath with my smart devices and boils down into actionable context. It shows me the medium term (weeks) benefits of exercise and gives me short term (today) confidence in my activity decisions.

I’m currently using Gentler Streak alongside Runna, Oura and Apple Fitness. Gentler Streak provides a useful additional perspective on the data.

I tried the Go Gentler suggested workouts for a while. I found I usually wanted to work harder than it suggested. I still use it for informal things like active housework and chasing my kids at the playground, but I currently prefer Runna for structured training.

title: Like it a lot, but two major flaws for me

content.text: I like this app much more than others, even Apple's and I would actually become paid user, however there are two flaws that are too big for me to ignore. First of all, the AWU action button doesn’t start designated activity most of the time, it seems that this feature wasn’t properly tested before release. Second is dog walking activity, as it seems that they just renamed it and took all the parameters from walking one. Dog walking includes frequent stops, turns, sometimes even circles and the app is constantly nagging with activity seems to be stopped screen. If those two things are fixed in the near future, I will probably opt-in for paid version.

content.text: If I forget to end my walk, this app will keep on adding minutes to my time while I'm sitting still for 15 minutes or more. When I didn't "end" before I took my watch off & it went into Nightstand Mode, it added an 8 hour overnight walk. I know my Apple watch knows when I stop moving - I know there's a coder someplace who could fix this: don't know why the folks behind this app don't take the trouble to find one.

title: A few things missing from apple app

This app, along with managing my diet, have aided significantly in bettering my health. Thanks!

title: Have to have an Apple Watch to use app.

content.text: The app is otherwise fine but, you have to have an Apple Watch to use it. I don’t have one, and I can’t see my steps like I would with other apps. Gentler does help me keep being active because I have to log in the app what exercise I did. Example: today I did an hour and 32 minute bike ride, and it made me type what time I started, what time I ended, and what type of exercise I did, unlike most apps which automatically log your exercise.

content.text: I really want to love this app. There’s a lot I do love about it. But it seems to continuously think that I am pushing myself too hard, when really I feel like I’m being too light. It’s been this way for a couple of weeks now. It thinks that my “usual range” for exertion is at the bottom of the gauge and seemingly refuses to update that impression. There really needs to be some way of resetting the app’s expectations of my fitness, because it seems to think that I can’t even take a light walk every day without telling me to take it easy. So at the moment it’s very pretty but kind of useless. I’ll update my review if they can add a workaround for this other than “just wait it out.”

content.text:
Been using for a few days and already love it! I would give a 4.5 if I could. The one feature I'd most like to see added is a "chronic illness" mode. I got the premium version as an alternative to the much pricier Visible Health subscription. I do love that Gentler Streak tells me when I'm pushing too hard, but it'd be awesome to have an option for saying I have a chronic illness that requires more days of rest that most people / a lower exertion threshold, a place to add in medications and conditions that impact HR, conditions that impact sleep and fatighe, etc.
Otherwise a great app! If you don't have an energy-limiting illness it's an excellent way to move more without the guilt.

content.text:
I’m not a competitive athlete. I’m an old fart and just want an app to help me stay healthy as long as possible. GS helps me stay motivated by tracking a few personal health and exercise metrics. I’ve tried a bunch of the heavy hitters, but most of them are all about social media or flooded with ads. Gentler Streak is just about perfect for me. It track my bike rides, walks and stretching, yoga and strength training, encourages me when I’ve been lazy for too long and even yells at me when I overdo it. I only wish it would read a few other metrics from Apple Health and display them along with the ones built into the ‘wellbeing’ tab, but I guess if they did that for everybody the app would end up being a bloated mess. Still, 95% perfect and (though I despise suckscriptions) Gentler Streak is one of the few I’ll willingly pay.

** edit ** And congratulations on being recognized by Apple as a 2024 Design Award winner!

title: Gentler Streak falls short of expectations

content.text:
I subscribed to Gentler Streak for about a year, but I’ve decided not to renew my subscription. Initially, I was drawn to the app because I thought its name suggested a focus on overall fitness goals in a balanced and supportive manner. However, my experience was quite different. The app frequently categorized my efforts as either over-reaching or slacking, which didn't align with my expectations for a "gentler" approach to fitness.

One aspect of the app that stands out positively is its feature to help you train during your menstrual cycle. While this is a thoughtful addition, it’s not relevant for me since I no longer have menstrual cycles.

In terms of performance, Gentler Streak does a decent job tracking cardio activities. However, it falls short when it comes to strength training. The app's capabilities in this area are lacking, which is a significant drawback if your fitness regimen includes a substantial amount of strength work.

That said, Gentler Streak could be beneficial if you are a runner training for marathons or races. The app seems well-suited for tracking and optimizing cardio efforts, making it a good companion for dedicated runners. 

Overall, while Gentler Streak has some merits, it doesn't quite meet my needs for a comprehensive fitness tracking app.

title: Great App but charges early adopters more

content.text:
I love this app and use it all the time. It is a great substitute for Whoop which costs $30/month

I usually keep a 5 star review for Gentler Streak, except that I am currently super disappointed that I am unable to signup with a Lifetime subscription. Apparently, since I’ve been a subscriber since 2022, someone has decided that they should keep billing me every year and not allow me the option of a Lifetime subscription.

I cancelled my annual subscription renewal and have a few months to find a better option. Maybe after this years subscription runs out I’ll be able to signup for the Lifetime option.

title: The App That Gets Me Moving

content.text: Gentler Streak does what many other apps try and fail to do: it gets me moving. Most health apps (especially nutrition apps) are bloated and ask all sorts of questions I have no desire to engage with (hello “What’s your goal weight?”). But Gentler Streak has distilled an important part of daily movement down to the essentials. And it has helped me form a contract with myself. Every day I have the opportunity to wake up and promise to myself that I’ll do my best to do a little more today than I did yesterday. And that simplicity is powerful.

title: It’s not just about PACE…it’s about peace of mind!

content.text:
The "Gentler Streak" fitness app encourages a self-compassionate approach to exercise and provides a balance between fitness and rest. It offers personalized suggestions for daily workout actions, which can range from rest to intense workouts. It helps me - a 67 year old guy who values a balanced approach to fitness and well-being - stay within healthy activity levels. 

With an intuitive UI, it’s so easy to use, even my grandma could do it—and she can’t tell a smartwatch from her headstone. It’s easy to understand and won’t leave you sweating the small stuff.

The app’s feedback is so encouraging, it’s like having a cheerleader in your pocket. It’ll lift your spirits higher than a kettlebell! 
Additionally, the app provides relevant, actionable insights and expert knowledge in short reads. 

It earns 5 👍🏼👍🏼👍🏼👍🏼👍🏼 from me!

title: No trial period for most features.

content.text: I was really excited to use this app, since I frankly find the Apple Health app unusable in terms of understanding metrics, but I was super disappointed because basically all of the features are locked behind the paywall. To be clear, I’m not against paying for an app that works and is genuinely helpful, but if I can’t see what I’m paying for, then why should I spend any money? They advertise a 48-hour promotion to buy an annual subscription… why not give us a 48-hour trial to even see if it’s worth it?

content.text: There was a time in my life when I was an Ironman triathlete, but a combination of COVID, heavy workload and aging had my fitness levels drop significantly over recent years. Gentler Streaks has been fantastic in helping me to get back into shape, giving me a supportive and *gentle* push to gradually increase my activity without wearing myself out or yo-yo’ing into and out of cycles of exercise. The interface is great and easy to follow, the technical side of the app is excellent, and the feedback is fun. I use this app everyday and find it to be a great compliment to Apple Fitness+.

title: Pretty App to Designed to Keep You On the Sofa

content.text:
It’s a cute app, and I love the concept. 

However, I am accustomed to 2-3 workouts a week. These vary intensity. My Apple Watch says my cardio fitness is “above average” and I feel I have normal recovery times. I’m far from a fitness junky, but like average fit I’d say. 

I just came back to logging after taking a break (but not a break from working out) and gentler streak tells me my 27 minute gentle Pilates session (my heart rate was in zones “0” and “1” according to Gentler puts me into “over exertion”. That going for a slow walk for the morning after is “too much”. 

If you want an app that congratulates you for doing a singular workout and gives you an excuse to “rest” for days after any moderate effort … Sign on up. If you actually want something to give you insights on your health and fitness and encourages you to improve, move along.

title: BEST workout tracker !!! With one request

content.text:
I ADORE this app!! I have a pretty bad tendency to push myself too hard when I workout, and this app has helped me so much to always have an idea of where my body is at and if I need to back off. It helps me stay on track and lets me know when I need to get a workout in (wouldn’t want to lose my streak of course). I especially love that the messages are written like a friend encouraging you to stay with it and keep going without being harsh or feeling shameful. 

The one feature that would make this so much better is if there was a notes section inside each activity after they’ve been completed. When you open the activities tab and select a recently completed activity, I imagine that there could be a “notes” section under “charts” and “perceived exertion.” I usually record my workouts as “strength training” but have a tendency to forget when the last time was that I worked a certain muscle group. As a college student I can’t always go to the gym consistently so I get workouts in when I can. This means I don’t have a set weekly workout schedule and must try to remember the last time I hit legs lol. Having a section for notes would make it so much easier to remember when I did certain workouts, or it could even be used as a way to track weight and reps for the day. I’ve been trying to find a way to track these things either on my own or in an app and it just doesn’t seem like anything exists for this purpose and/or is easy to use. In addition to a notes section, it could be helpful to be able to add a title or subtitle to an activity to more easily identify details about it. This could look like “strength training - Legs” where the original title of the activity remains, but you are able to add quick details to the log. 
I already love this app so much and use it for every workout, but if this feature could be added my love for gentler would just grow even more. I think it would really enhance the already amazing experience and make workout tracking that much easier.

title: Great for Novice, not great for serious training

content.text:
I love that Gentler Streak makes it simple and easy for folks who are just beginning their fitness journey. However, if you are a serious athlete training for a marathon, 15 K, or some other endurance race this is probably not the app for you. I have been training for eight weeks and recently completed a 8 mile run. I took a day off to recover, and then the following day the app said I was pushing too hard, 1 mile in to a 2 mile active recovery run. I know my body and I know when it is time to lay off. Being in tune with my body and whether or not, it’s ready after recovery is something that comes with years of training and experience.

Again, this is great for those just beginning, or just wanting to learn about their body and it’s response to stress from physical activity. It is not meant for rigorous and experienced endurance athletes.

content.text:
Context: 66 yrs female. 
Never been athletic or get a charge from achieving goals or competitive games. I’m past my “prime” as they say. I am constantly managing the possibility of inducing a migraine after exercise. However, the truth is that not exercising feeds depression, arthritis, dementia, insomnia, osteoporosis, dullness, and weight gain. 
Go Gentler has been my friend and coach while I navigate staying fit. I found this Go Gentler app after I purchased the expensive Apple Watch (which was a great investment!). Coupling the app with Apples Health Tracker has been so helpful to assess my ups and downs and to stay positive about myself.

title: Stop comparing activity to food consumed

content.text:
I enjoy this app, but I can’t recommend it to a friend who would love it because you compare calories burned to food. She has an eating disorder, and if you won’t take this feature off the app altogether, it should at least be something you can turn off.

Its harmful to think about movement this way. If this app is meant to be gentler, then we need to motivate movement for our wellbeing, not to counteract what we put in our bodies to stay alive.

content.text: In my opinion, this app doesn’t really measure activity well; it frequently tells me I’m over reaching to the point where I don’t even log workouts—a thirty minute walk plus 30 minutes of yoga is not over reaching, at least not for me. I get that for some people it might be, but with my current fitness levels and history of amount of time working out, the app should know after three months that this is a normal amount of activity for me. I guess if you want to be very, very gently coaxed into doing a bit more activity, this app will work, but if you want to challenge yourself and if you’re already fairly active, I’d suggest looking elsewhere.

title: This is the BEST health, wellness, and fitness tracker I’ve ever used

content.text:
I became aware of this app at the beginning of 2023 after searching for one to help me with my New Year resolution. I wanted to assess better when to work out and which type I’ll do for each day. 

Each morning, this app helps me improve my self-care because of the metrics it provides about my previous night. I tried the one-week free trial before purchasing my annual subscription. Over the last year, I followed the Gentler Streak recommendation, and it has helped improve my wellness overall. 

I realized I was pushing too hard during some workouts and was not well enough to exercise on other days. Recommended rest days were always impactful.

title: A perfect alternative to Apple Fitness

content.text:
I love the personalized approach to fitness on this app! I still use my Apple Watch activity app to track my workouts since it’s what I’m familiar with, but I love that the two apps talk to each other back and forth so I can go into gentler streak and see my heart rate zones and understand when I might be overdoing it. 

A way way way more personal and maintainable approach to fitness, that doesn’t require you to set any unrealistic goals that you won’t stick with, and doesn’t focus on weight loss/calories.

title: After searching for over a decade…

content.text: This is the only workout app that has made me want to work out. The fact that it counts rest days as productive and encourages you not to lose your streak in a gentle way, is the best! Other apps are just about checking something off or marking it done, and when you miss one, you feel terrible. This gives you flexibility and as long as you’re in the progress zone, you’re good! Also love it talks to the health app, so if I’m doing a workout with another app that talks to the health app, Gentle Streak marks it too. Love love love this app!

title: Don’t use if you’re interested in increasing fitness

content.text: This app is not for anyone looking to improve their fitness level. Any time I actually exercise, it cries at me or chastises me and calls me an overachiever. And I mean, if all I do is a slow 3 mile jog or a moderate 30 minute strength training session, it gives me grief. The only days I don’t get chewed out by this app are days that I am not exercising. I tried it for two months to see if I could figure out how to increase my fitness activity without it whining at me or complaining, and I never could. Deleting. Waste of money.

title: I love this app! Two wishes…

content.text:
As a long-time endurance athlete, it’s easy to get sucked into comparison. My friend did this, I’m falling behind. Oh, my run today was really slow, I need to make an excuse in my Strava workout description so people have context and don’t think poorly of me. It’s more exhausting than the actual long runs. 

Gentler is the perfect antidote. Instead of obsessing over what other people are doing or the optics of what I’m doing, I can focus on what my body needs. Novel idea in the age of social media! Plus it still has the data I need to train effectively, unlike many “alternative” exercise tracking apps. 

Also love that the nutrition and exercise tips are rooted in science, not diet culture. Whole posts about how beneficial carbs and fat are? Major green flag 💚

I only have two complaints, and these are missing features/opportunities rather than broken current ones. 

1. I wish there was better integration for folks not using an Apple Watch. I have a very nice GPS watch with the battery life needed for running ultras, so no intention of ever switching to an Apple Watch.

Unfortunately, I run into barriers with this app, like not being able to use or even view the suggested Gentler workouts. I wish there was a way to export them to Coros, or even just look at their details in the app so I can manually program a workout on my watch (or at least know what to shoot for).

2. I wish I could edit activities, especially activity types, within the Gentler app. Once an activity is exported from my watch to the app, I can’t edit the type. 

So for example, since my watch doesn’t have a specific yoga mode and I use the “gym cardio” mode, Gentler views my yoga activities as weightlifting (or other), and I can’t change it. Same goes for trail running, mountain biking, etc. Gentler offers those as supported activities types but I wish I could change my already imported workouts to those supported types like is possible in Strava.

It’s not the end of the world, but when viewing monthly and yearly data, I’d love to be able to differentiate between days I actually lifted weights and when I did yoga, or how many times I rode my mountain bike versus road bike.

At the end of the day, pretty minor things that won’t keep me from using the app, but I think it would take the overall user experience to a new level!

Thank you for making an app for recovering comparison addicts like myself. It’s really helpful for reframing my fitness journey and helping me focus on the activity and how it benefits my body instead of how it looks to others.

I have a very nice GPS watch with the battery life needed for running ultras, so no intention of ever switching to an Apple Watch. Unfortunately, I run into barriers with this app, like not being able to use or even view the suggested Gentler workouts. I wish there was a way to export them to Coros, or even just look at their details in the app so I can manually program a workout on my watch (or at least know what to shoot for). 2. I wish I could edit activities, especially activity types, within the Gentler app. Once an activity is exported from my watch to the app, I can’t edit the type. So for example, since my watch doesn’t have a specific yoga mode and I use the “gym cardio” mode, Gentler views my yoga activities as weightlifting (or other), and I can’t change it. Same goes for trail running, mountain biking, etc. Gentler offers those as supported activities types but I wish I could change my already imported workouts to those supported types like is possible in Strava. It’s not the end of the world, but when viewing monthly and yearly data, I’d love to be able to differentiate between days I actually lifted weights and when I did yoga, or how many times I rode my mountain bike versus road bike. At the end of the day, pretty minor things that won’t keep me from using the app, but I think it would take the overall user experience to a new level! Thank you for making an app for recovering comparison addicts like myself. It’s really helpful for reframing my fitness journey and helping me focus on the activity and how it benefits my body instead of how it looks to others.

content.text: The app in question was a textbook example of a subpar user experience. Its interface was cluttered and confusing, making it a challenge to navigate and find the desired features. The app frequently crashed, leaving users frustrated and often unable to complete even the most basic tasks. To add to the frustration, it bombarded users with intrusive and irrelevant ads, disrupting the overall usability. Furthermore, customer support was virtually non-existent, making it nearly impossible to address any issues or seek assistance. In sum, the app's poor design, constant crashes, and lack of support made it an infuriating and overall unpleasant experience for users.

title: Loved until the watch app stopped working

content.text:
Update: 
My watch just aged out of the app. If you have a newer Apple Watch, it should work great for you. Huge bummer that my otherwise perfectly functional device will no longer support this app that I used all day everyday but I guess maybe I can get back into regular use when I am able to afford a new watch 🤷🏻‍♀️. Better than the Apple fitness rings if it works on your Watch. 

Original review:
I started paying for this app earlier this year and absolutely loved it for the first half of 2023. After an update about a month ago, maybe longer, the watch app totally stopped working then disappeared from my watch. I have tried redownloading to my watch periodically since incase it is fixed by a subsequent update and every time I am told the download failed and to try again later. Anyone else having this problem? I really loved the app so I hope it is resolved quickly.

title: After a full week of resting I’m still “overreaching”

content.text:
I don’t know what the intent behind this app is, because all it seems to say is that I’m overreaching. I took two short (10 min ea) bike rides and it said I was overreaching for a day before telling me to exercise. Then I took one long bike ride (2 hrs) a week ago and today it still says I’m overreaching and need to rest. I haven’t even taken walks since then! If you want to build your fitness level go find an app that will actually push you. If you want to feel good about being lazy download this app. 

 Edit: I just got a message that I need to log a workout (even though I just did one yesterday) and it STILL says I’m overreaching.

Edit 2: I didn’t open it for a couple weeks and the widget said for all of that time that I was either well rested or overreaching. It never said I was on the right track and it took days to go from overreaching to the well rested, never stopping in the middle. Then today I got a mea culpa message when I opened the app saying their onboarding was messed up and they were going to fix that. Near as I can tell nothing has been fixed. Go find another app, this one is not good.

content.text: Generally a good app, good advice and creates a useful record, but one BIG problem.  The problem is that sometimes I inadvertently hit a button on my watch and the app records a workout that becomes a permanent part of my record though nothing really happened.  I need the ability to edit and tweak the records created to make sure they properly reflect what I actually did.  Without that, the records are faulty and not nearly so useful as the app would like to make me think they are.

content.text:
You’re doing great! Keep it up! 

That’s all great but give me some data. I want to know when I should push harder and how hard compared to yesterday or ??  Give me something. Other apps use all of the health data that Gentler does but other apps give you a “where is your recovery” today and a goal range. It doesn’t say walk x miles but lets you know to take it easy today or if I’m near 100% and push hard. Every day I have a long workout or game, Gentler gives me a “hold up buddy. Know your limits”. 

I guess this is ok for most people (based on reviews) but I want a little more than a pat on the back and a “keep it up!”

Interface is nice for what it is. Cheers

This is coming from a former US Marine & current SWAT team member. 

Thanks for your hard work on this app. I wish you all the best and hope for long lasting success for your app.

But also adding a customizable alarm for either watch, phone or iPad, or all of them with an adjustable 15-30 minute wake window for smooth wakening, and multiple smooth alarm options. Just as Sleep Cycle has done.

title: Ridiculous and discouraging feedback from app

content.text:
I’ve used the app over two months and found if anything it has a negative impact on my physical health and the statements about my health just piss me off. I spent a week on vacation walking and hiking in the mountains. Even on light days that I considered no exertion the app screamed at me that I was overdoing it. After returning home and not exercising for 2 days it was still threatening that dire things would happen if I didn’t rest. Then I wake this morning to it flipping 180 over night and now telling me my fitness is in decline from not exercising! Sadly, inaccurate, alarming, and wildly extreme comments like this are normal for this app. 
The flip flopping and inaccuracy of the comments makes this worthless. Wish I hadn’t spent money on it but the free/trial version was too pared down to know what it does. Going back to just using apple fitness, it actually reflects what I do in a day whether I start it tracking or not.

title: The right way to be (re)introduced to fitness

content.text:
Gentler Streaks makes fitness accessible to all. It lowers the barrier to entry (your own mind!) and does so in a fun and delightful way. As someone who has always had a complicated relationship with fitness and who has tried lots of apps to track workouts or provide motivation, this one is by far the best.

Gentler Streaks combines the tracking necessities with the appropriate motivation to help you continually achieve your fitness goals. No matter if you’re a novice runner or an expert powerlifter, there’s something in this app for you. It’ll tell you when it’s time to give your body a break and when it’s time to push to the next level.

The added benefit of Wellbeing, which utilizes sleep tracking data, is something I have yet to explore as I don’t sleep with my watch on, however I’m considering adding that to my routine since I’m so happy with the rest of the functionality in this app.

Love to see the continued updates being pushed frequently and Gentler Streaks getting better and better. Keep up the great work. 🏋🏻

title: Don’t use Apple health vo2 max to assess fitness.

content.text:
Gentler streak is using Apple health’s Vo2max assessment to plot an activity path, unfortunately Apple’s vo2max assessment doesn’t take into consideration the fact that when I hike I’m walking steep mountain trails, carrying a heavy pack, and so it assumes I’m far less fit than I am. 
That breaks the deal for me, either be accurate or I’m not interested.

title: Not worth it if you don’t have an Apple Watch

content.text: I love the idea, but you really need an Apple Watch to make it work. In theory, it’s supposed to work as long as all your data is in the apple health app. But if you don’t have a fitness tracker, or your tracker is a Fitbit, all your data isn’t going to be in the apple health app, and then it’s not going to do much for you. (There are separate 3rd party apps that sync Fitbit with AH, but they all seem sketchy - personally I don’t like to give out my data like that.) You have to pay to be able to add things to Gentler Streaks manually, and even then it keeps displaying things about fitness trackers, like telling you to wear your smartwatch to bed. They should really make it clear up front that 99% of the functions are based on having an Apple Watch.

title: Great premise, very slow to load 🫤

content.text:
I really love the concept of the app, but it is incredibly slow to open and load data (noticeably slower than other data intensive apps). If I’m trying to get a quick sense of where I’m at in the day this is often enough delay that I just close the app and move on. If I open a month in review, it has to process the data again it seems, even if I’ve looked at the month before.

I like that the app helps focus on relative effort, and encourages you to get back into things, well, gently. It’s so much nicer than apps that don’t afford any rest time or that don’t account for overall wellness when setting goals and determining steaks.

I’ll keep with it for now at least!

content.text:
I expected a lot more out of a $30 app. The rest tracker is interesting and what drew me into the app, but I wouldn’t have paid $30 if I knew that was essentially all it was.

The data it tracks can already be tracked via your apple watch, fitness, and health app. The rest of the content is pretty worthless as well. It’s a bunch of regurgitated summaries of fitness articles. 

I could maybe see this being helpful if you are 100% new fitness but the app doesn’t offer much else if you’re already on your fitness journey. 

Beyond the rest tracker you’re basically paying $30/year to reskin the fitness and health app that already comes on your phone.

title: An app that finally validates my daily movements.

content.text:
At my current job, I end up walking between 14k-24k steps (~7-12 miles) in a singular 5-10 hour shift. It’s exhausting both physically and mentally, and there’s obviously no point in me trying to add in an “official” walk/run exercise on any of the days that I’m working.

I was a bit hesitant to try this app out after reading a handful of reviews that talked about how they “wished the activity path would include daily steps” in it’s calculations. Obviously, the only metric I’m actually measuring while at work IS, in fact, my daily step count, alongside occasional heart rate readings and “idle” exercise minutes (~60-150min total) that get tracked outside of official workouts.

DAILY STEPS DO HAVE AN EFFECT ON THE ACTIVITY PATHWAY!

I don’t know how many daily steps those other reviewers were counting, but I can see a major difference in my activity path between the 4 days that I work 9-10 hours, the day I work 5 hours, and the 2 days I get off during the week. The difference is blatantly obviously when you move as much as I do during a work shift.

This app really makes me feel validated in my physical fitness. I can’t begin to tell you how many times I would come home from work and think to myself something along the lines of, “You shouldn’t be this tired. You’re not doing much of anything worth feeling tired over.” But this app is the first thing to tell me that I’m pushing myself hard, that I’m edging towards the limits of my physical capabilities, that I should take a day to rest and recover (which I sadly can’t because it’s my job).

The “Go Gentler” workouts are also really nice. I really like the interface on the Apple Watch and how it shows you your HR zones as the default screen during an exercise. (I know Apple’s Exercise app supposedly has a screen for HR zones too but I can’t figure out how to show that while exercising.)

I think my one recommendation/request for this app going forward would be the ability to customize the “Go Gentler” workouts, which doesn’t seem to be an option as far as I can tell. Apple’s Exercise app lets you set up custom workouts with intervals, repetitions, and has the option for warmup and cooldown times. If there was a way to do that with the “Go Gentler” workouts too, I think this app would be nearing perfection.

title: Amazing app for creating sustainable movement habit

content.text: As someone who has never consistently exercised, this app is brilliant at telling me to slow down. Why is this important? Because habits are created slowly, incrementally, not by busting out maximum effort sporadically. Can’t recommend this enough if you are an all-or-nothing person who tends toward nothing if you can’t do it perfectly. Love this app!

title: Wouldn’t buy again- buy ‘training today’ app instead

content.text: I thought this would give me “insight” as to how to workout to “stay on track”. And what types of workouts .. with more specificity. And it does … sort of  …. BUT all it does so far is give me the suggestion of heart rate zone 4 and just makes my minutes less on any of my normal workouts. So it’ll literally suggest I go take an outdoor bike ride for 5 min if I ask it to adjust to a lower “level”. Really?! I thought it would be much more informative. And even giving me some sort of workout plan. I also thought it would directly me whether i *should* rest or push. Training today app is much better on this front of telling me by my biometrics if my body should rest. Def won’t buy again.

I just subscribed for a year because I love the iPhone app and the metrics. I also like the design of the workout screens on the watch, but the performance has been really bad. 
The running workout auto-pause takes like 2min to realize you have stopped, and if I decide to pause manually, the app crashes and I lose all of the GPS tracking before the app froze. Totally unreliable metrics. Going to stick with the Apple workouts for now…
Also, I wish there were more settings available for the watch app, like heart rate (audio) alerts. Couldn’t find that.

title: Still needs a bit of work

content.text:
UPDATE: We still aren’t getting anything to show our steps as activity in this app. That’s a critical issue here. We shouldn’t have to log our daily steps as workouts to record the activity. I’ve tried doing this to have a more accurate picture of wellbeing and actually have the app saying I’m overreaching when it’s not that hard to walk throughout the day, taking breaks in between. Developers need to find a way to work this into the algorithm for the app. As it stands it seems that while other apps ignore the need for customization based on individual abilities/needs this app ignores the need to have basic data at its core. We need to meet somewhere in the middle here ASAP. 
————
I like the app but there are area it needs work; 1) The new Wellbeing tab and syncing with Health is good, but why doesn’t it show our steps? and why aren’t our streaks reflecting our walking throughout the day? This needs attention ‼️ 2) I’ve had to edit sleep in other apps as it over estimated my time sleeping. But then this app shows “Insufficient data” under the Wellbeing tab.🤨 The day is there? I just corrected it so that the record is accurate. This shouldn’t be a problem. 3) One of the reasons I’ve liked this app is the ability to do things at our own pace. I don’t like the “reminders” about exercising or losing a streak. A streak shouldn’t rely solely on workouts but also steps. See point 1.

title: Great app! Could be even better.

content.text:
I love the concept and the delivery of this app. I appreciate being able to take a pause and tweak settings so I can prevent disordered eating triggers and I can modify the level of rigor of the app. I love the positivity and that I feel like I can come back after an illness or rough mental health week. I also love that it takes my physical health into consideration helps me keep an eye on my metrics. I can even tell when I don’t use my CPAP machine for a night, which keeps me motivated to use the machine!

Features I would love to see, as a currently subscribed user: - Goals. I don’t always have time or energy to work out daily, but I’m not “sick” or “on a break”. Streaks (the app that inspired this app) allows me to adjust the timeframe that I complete my goals, such as 3x per week. In Gentler Streaks, I’d love to be able to set my fitness goals at 3x per week and then if I fall behind, the app lets me know if I need to “step up my game.” - Ability to modify messages. I would like to be able to change the text, for instance where it says “Step up your game.” Making the app more customizable would be better for everyone, no matter the desired level of rigor. Adding these features would make this a 5-star app.

title: Streak and well-being slow after update

content.text:
Update 2: It’s now crashing whenever it tries to generate the streak or well-being sections. I’m bummed. 

Updated: The problem is continuing and has gotten worse. The support team is very responsive, but so far they haven’t come up with a solution. I’m seriously bummed. When it’s working I love this app! It’s the first one that figured out how to actually motivate me to get active. Unfortunately, since the last update the streak section and the well-being section take a really long time to load—like several minutes (my phone keeps falling asleep before it’s done)—and that’s immensely frustrating.

title: The best fitness app out there and the only one that doesn’t punish you for rest

content.text:
I’ve tried multiple fitness apps but none of them really stuck. Gentler Streaks is different. It helps keep me motivated while also giving me permission to rest when I need it. I find seeing my Activity Path slowly rise up gives me concrete evidence that I’m improving and motivates me further to keep things going.  

When using it on the Apple Watch, it functions very similar to Apple’s native workout app. This I like, because I enjoy the setup of Apple’s workout app and ease of use. However, unlike Apple, it offers you the chance to change your status from active to injured, sick, or on a break. This is what sets it apart because with Apple and other fitness apps, if you lose one day you’re punished for it by losing your streaks, even if you’re injured or sick. Gentler Streaks understands that you shouldn’t be punished for being injured, sick, or simply on vacation. Everyone needs a break sometimes and when you want to start things up again, you can switch back to “active” and Gentler Streaks will give you a fitness plan that won’t burn you out or cause you to reinjure yourself.  

There are two recommendations I would give to make this app even better.

The first is that I wish there was a better way to see your progress over time. You get a monthly and yearly recap, but I’d like the option to look at my Activity Path and see how it changes over time whenever I want to. You see the past ten days, and like I said before seeing the difference does help motivate me, but I’d like to zoom out a little further whenever I wanted to.   

The second is that I’d love to see more articles/insights! There’s a good selection right now, but I love reading these articles and learning more about how I can improve. As a copywriter though, I understand how long it can take to cobble an article together so I understand why there aren’t more right now :)

content.text:
Update: I’ve had this app 4+ months now and still do not see the value. I do not plan to renew my subscription and do not think it is worth the cost. 

Things that don’t make sense to me and could use improvement:
- you can only see the last 10 days of your activity path (so you cannot see long term improvements or decline in activity)
- any activity that you do that is not logged as a workout does not affect your activity path
- many (all?) workouts logged through this app seem to count 100% toward your exercise ring (rather than only counting walking that is brisk enough)
- per the previous two points, if I log 90 min. of “Daily Chores” so that my activity for the day is reflected in this app, it counts as 90 min. of exercise in my apple health app
- the wellness tab and the activity path don’t work well together. I’ve had days where the wellness tab tells me to take it easy but the activity path tells me I need to step it up or I’m going to fall off my activity path

Initial Review: I’ve been subscribed for at least a couple of months now. I have yet to see the real value this provides beyond the workout tracking that is available and built into the Apple Watch. I am intrigued to see how the Wellness tab possibly enhances this app. BUG: The sleep info in the wellness tab is incorrect. It seems you are only pulling in the sum of the stages of sleep. For example, my health app says I slept 8h 48m but your app says 6h 34m.

content.text: I purchased this app on sale as I was searching for something to manage stress and ran across this app. So far, it’s been great tracking my stats. I love seeing my numbers in an easy to follow graph and it is always spot on when telling me perhaps I need to rest. Each time I have been feeling sluggish or unwell, the app “knows” based on my data. This has helped me take it easy when I otherwise would continue to push myself just because of my Type A personality. The app gives me the reassurance to listen to my body and put my well-being first. I absolutely love the app!

title: Neat App But Seems to Lack Accuracy

content.text:
This is a great app. I love the way the information is laid out. I love the design a lot. I only have two gripes. 

1. For context, I wear an Apple Watch Ultra almost 24/7. I am in good health. I’m a long distance trail runner. I spend a lot of time on my feet every week. I’m not fast, but I do speedwork (whatever that is for a 49 year old) about once per week. Go Gentler doesn’t seem to take into account current fitness levels or heart rate data. It seems to be mostly based on time. I could do a slow two hour run, and it will push me into the “overreaching” zone even though I’m in zone 2 most of the time. Then I do a “fast” 5k, and it barely registers as a workout. I may be more tired from the 5k, but the app is telling me to do more. Not correct. I’ve used other apps (e.g., Athlytic) that handle the data better. 

2. If you use the track bar graph instead of the single line, it constantly moves and tries to show you how you can “sneak” ahead into the future. I get it. I got it the first time. Don’t show me that and give haptic feedback *every single time,* please. I switched to the single line because it was so annoying. 

I paid for an annual subscription because overall, I do love the app. But I hope to see improvements.

content.text:
It’s definitely a healthier approach than apple’s “close your rings everyday” approach. I bought the annual subscription and use the widget to keep keep an eye on my zones throughout the week. It’s a newer app, so I’m sure there’s a lot of great features on the way. After using it for few months here are my notes for improvement: 1. The app almost always says I’m overreaching. I’ve been working out 3x a week for one hour each morning doing moderate - intense weight training g. This has been my routine for months and it still says I’m pushing too hard. Perhaps add a way to adjust zones or customize it based on goals. 2. The zones seem arbitrary. As a user I have absolutely no clue how the graph is calculated or how the data I’m plugging in actually impacts future projections. Adding some reading material for us to reference that gets into the nitty gritty aspects of your algorithm would be helpful. 3. Analyze past Apple Health data/ allow back scrolling by more than 10 days. This might already be done, but that’s not apparent. Another benefit would include automatically giving personalized zones. 4. Minor but an Apple Watch-style ring closing notifications that tell me if I’m on track would be neat. I originally switched to replace that feature. Overall this is a great app and the UI is on point. The algorithm discourages pushing myself to the point of it almost being negative (coincidentally this leads me to ignore the “overreaching” alerts). However I feel it’s taught me to listen to my body more. I’m excited to see what your team has in store!

UPDATE
I appreciate the response. I have been using my Apple Watch for 18 months consistently, and gradually increased my workout with a personal trainer. Therefore the “overworking” algorithm appears to have bugs (cited by others, not just me.)
Since writing the review I have decided to switch back to Apple’s native health app. While the daily rings isn’t ideal, it offers a more robust analysis of my workout patterns. I look forward to trying Gentler Streak in the future when some more features have been added!

title: Pretty, supportive, but based on science?

content.text:
First, the app is visually appealing and offers positive support & encouragement for health & fitness goals. But I’m not sure if the goals/guidance it gives you are based on science or… what, biorhythms? There used to be this range of effort that would fluctuate up and down over time, with the app encouraging you to stay within that zone, but I don’t know what that zone was based on. 

Next, I subscribed for a year because it seemed useful, but without the specific explanation for what that zone was based on, it’s hard to be reassured that it actually meant something. Then after I let my subscription end, they tweaked the app so that zone is no longer visible at all - meaning that the free version just offers encouragement without anything more concrete. I let my sub lapse but I didn’t delete the app; after this change, I don’t see any reason to keep it anymore.

Then after I let my subscription end, they tweaked the app so that zone is no longer visible at all - meaning that the free version just offers encouragement without anything more concrete. I let my sub lapse but I didn’t delete the app; after this change, I don’t see any reason to keep it anymore.
content.cleanHtml: Pretty, supportive, but based on science? First, the app is visually appealing and offers positive support & encouragement for health & fitness goals. But I’m not sure if the goals/guidance it gives you are based on science or… what, biorhythms? There used to be this range of effort that would fluctuate up and down over time, with the app encouraging you to stay within that zone, but I don’t know what that zone was based on. content.text:
Update:  I uninstalled this app after several months. While I commend the app developers for offering to give away licenses to those who are unable to pay the subscription, I don’t feel it’s the right thing to do to take advantage of such an offer.

Really, this should be a cheaper one-time purchase instead of soaking people for a subscription as so many other app developers do these days.

This app is worthless in free mode. With other similar excellent one-time purchase apps like Personal Best out there, I just can’t fathom paying what the developers want for this.

Original review below…

I have several really good fitness apps that I rely on. All charge a low one-time price for use. While this app looks like it will be a lot of fun to add to my routine, I can’t afford yet another subscription app. I wish developers would stop this practice

title: No idea why this was the app of the year 🙄

content.text:
I’ll fully admit I ain’t perfect and this could be user error and me failing to understand the app, but I find it completely useless and I’m very disappointed that I spent 30-odd doll hairs on something that is basically a daily reminder. I love the idea of having rest days in your health maintenance routine, but this ain’t it. 

Go Gentler doesn’t measure my activity the same way my watch does and it’s frustrating. It only counts what i log as a workout or do on Meta. For example, on a trip to NYC I  walked over 25K steps four days in a row, like LONG outdoor walls that I don’t count as a workout, but IT’S STILL EXERCISE. Then here comes this app like, “You seem rested! Time to step up your game.” …Really? 25K steps and yall acting like I didn’t exercise? Go sit down somewhere. 

Also, I hate the notifications that tell me I burned a banana and an orange or some jawn. It feels super condescending. Just gimme a number.

title: App is good but Well-being  is disappointing

content.text:
Been tracking my health metrics for years with iPhone and Apple Watch SE 2020. 

Wellbeing rolled out today and….. it says “insufficient data” because of too much interference (? Radio interference-what does interference mean). And I need to wear it while I sleep. (I have been wearing my Apple Watch since 2020 and tracking my sleep accordingly. 

If I look down it appears there is no oxygen and temp info because my watch doesn’t support it. 

I’m left to conclude that Well-being only works with later Apple Watches. If that is the case, why offer it to us who don’t have the feature and then blame it on interference (whatever interference is).

Bummed

content.text: I’m always the person to start going 110%, burn myself out, and stop working out for like a month because of it. I absolutely love this app because it’s finally gotten me back into regularly working out, at a healthy pace, and I feel incredible because I’m not burning myself out anymore. On top of the fact that the app’s features work wonders, it’s incredibly polished- every little button and slider feels great to use- every little thing seems like there was so much attention to detail put into it. The little flashes of colors, the incredible graphs, the little haptics that play when you slide a bar, everything is easy and fun to do. Massive kudos to the design team, from a designer myself.

content.text:
The algorithm they’re using to determine if you’re on track or need to rest is very, very basic. Like I think it’s only looking at duration of the activities I log manually and assuming I’m pushing myself to the limit.  It was telling me I need to go do something, so I logged the 3 hours of “daily chores” I did earlier in the day cleaning out the garage, which was in heart rate zone zero and I marked as just a little exertion. And then it said I was waaay overreaching! 

Whether it’s working as designed or not, I’m not learning much from this app about my fitness level and if I’m actually improving anything. It isn’t any more motivational than a plain old daily reminder.

content.text:
Overall, this app is fantastic. I use it exclusively on my Apple Watch. I have a request, though — and I think this is an opportunity Apple missed: I’d like to be able to cancel or abort a workout. 

I’m a homebody, and use Gentler Streak to track my morning household chores. But there are occasions where I’ve failed to stop the tracker. The next thing I know, another half hour has passed and I notice the tracker is still running. In those cases, a simple cancel button— perhaps beneath the “Done” one, and coupled with a “Do you really want to cancel?”  prompt — could stop the workout BEFORE it writes to the health data? I would much rather lose the 15 minutes of actual activity than keep a 45 minute instance I knew was false — I’d rather close the ring honestly and not have workouts later in the day affected by the mistake. 

Thank you so much!

content.text:
I’ve been enjoying the encouragement notifications the app gives me after my workouts but today I’m running late and what do I see? A notification saying “ EXERCISE REMINDER You're about to wave adios to your streak. Start a Go Gentler workout and get back in the game.”  

Not ok. I don’t know about other people but my willpower works on POSITIVE reinforcement, not negative. Not wanting to feel like a loser is not a motivation for me. Sometimes I need a day off for very good reasons. Telling me I’m about to say “adios” to my streak makes me want to skip a day just to spite you. 

Reminders like “You got this!” and “You’re doing great, don’t stop!” are what will keep me going. This app is so good otherwise and the negativity just seemed surprising. I hope they can update the app to either ditch the negative reinforcement or give us a choice.

Reminders like “You got this!” and “You’re doing great, don’t stop!” are what will keep me going. This app is so good otherwise and the negativity just seemed surprising. I hope they can update the app to either ditch the negative reinforcement or give us a choice.

title: Nifty for fitness, but harmful for womens health info

content.text:
Long story short: The fitness tracking seems good, but the womens health articles read like they’re written by a quack and shame contraceptive use for cramps. 

The app has seemed good so far, and I find it refreshing that they focus on not just active days, but rest days as well. It could be nice to be able to dig in a little deeper at times to understand how they come to their recommendations for you. I reeeaally don’t like their Womens Health articles, though. They frame menstrual cramps as if they’re the woman’s fault from being too stressed or having a poor diet. Yes, those things can contribute, but menstrual cramping is incredibly common and not just some behavioral issue that would be fixed if we all lived a little healthier. They also state that if you use contraceptives to for these issues, that you should “keep in mind they don’t really solve hormonal imbalances; they just clog up the symptoms”. One common cause of menstrual cramping is endometriosis. Endometriosis can be managed and prevented from progressing through the use of hormonal contraceptives. It doesn’t just “clog up the symptoms”. It’s a legitimate treatment for many health issues, and the alternative is other hormone treatment or surgery, which is far more invasive. Their description is not just misleading but almost like they’re shaming people who use contraceptives (or anything “synthetic”). This could easily be harmful to someone who doesn’t know much about the topic.

title: A very nice app and concept! But…

content.text:
The app’s concept is lovely! However, if you are a seasoned athlete or advanced fitness fanatic, this is probably not the app for you. As an advanced athlete myself, I find the app constantly thinks I am “overreaching” the healthy progress zone. Normal training for me seems to be overtraining according the activity bar. 

I do enjoy the insights, which is mainly my purpose for using it at this point haha. But this is definitely an app geared more toward those in the beginning and intermediate stages of their fitness journey!

title: Very pleasant interface. Possibly too gentle?

content.text:
I just downloaded the app, and I REALLY enjoy the aesthetic of this application. It is very fun to interact with and I’m excited to check back in to see how it interprets my data.

I understand this app might be tailored to individuals who are just beginning their wellness/fitness/etc. journeys, but is there a way to raise the “overreaching” limit? Or possibly make the message more supportive? As soon as I plugged in my information Yorhart told me I was overreaching, when actually I’m feeling pretty enthusiastic about my training and life in general right now.

Or maybe the “overreaching” limit doesn’t need to be raised. But users are presented with goal options, and based on what goals we select Yorhart will support us differently?

- “Recovering from an injury? You might be overreaching.”

- “Hey there! Remember if your goal is to balance your personal and professional life, you may be slightly overreaching for your goal.”

- Or, “Hey go getter! Congratulations on exceeding your goal once again! Keep up the hard work and you’ll be setting a new goal before you know it!”

I hope any of this was worth while, and doesn’t sound too critical. I really enjoy the app, and even though it is literally called “Gentler Streak” I would just love to see a more supportive message when I’m feeling like a go getter. There’s so much potential here. And I will definitely keep using and sharing!

Thank you!

content.text:
This seems like a seriously useful app. It's really got the right idea and the app really seems polished and clean without bugs. Great job on that. 

After using it for a week I notice it says I'm overreaching when I'm definitely not. I feel better than before. And I believe that's due to a couple reasons. It doesn't take into account sleep and it also doesn't take into account untracked activity. One of the missing ingredients here that make this app difficult to trust is that it doesn't tap into the Apple Watches ability to track other metrics in the background. Say I walk 15k steps that day in a bit of an abnormal day (this wasn't intentional exercise and I didn't track it) gentler streak has no idea and is still urging me to hit my target. The inverse is also true, if I have a lot of untracked activity history, gentler streak isn't accounting for that so it's really setting the bar low and telling me I'm constantly over reaching when really, I'm not. 
It also doesn't account for sleep which can also be tracked by a variety of devices and then pulled from apple health. I may sleep really great and be fully recovered but it makes no impact on how much I can do the next day. 

I would also like to know with a little more clarity if I follow the path, will I actually start to increase my fitness? Or will the path always peak me under what I'm capable of? Right now as it's constantly "overreaching" I feel a bit stifled. I know that's the point, but the problem is it tells me I'm pushing hard when I'm definitely not. I would like to feel like I'm actually overreaching when it says it.

title: Finally a workout tracker that makes sense

content.text: I’ve been using this app for about a month now and I absolutely love it. I don’t feel pushed to workout when my body is worn out. It lets me know when I need to step it up or if what I’m doing will maintain my current fitness level. It also tells me when I absolutely need a rest or I’ll hurt myself. It’s simple to use and understand. This is the motivation and guidance I’ve been needing. I have been consistent in my work outs since downloading this app and I feel better about actually working out. I highly recommend trying this app.

content.text:
I really like the idea of having rest days built into your streaks, but the execution in this app is just generally not great. There is almost no real data to look at, and if you do want to look at longer term trends it’s buried away in a non-intuitive manner. For example, you can’t scroll past the current week on the main view. 

I like the graph view of my activity compared to prior days (instead of rings) but I didn’t find it worth the subscription (or buying the app outright, which I do appreciate the option for!!)

content.text:
First off, I’m writing this on my iPad cause it’s lots easier than hunt-peck on the iPhone. I’m surprised to find the app on the iPad, nonetheless, opening it I discovered I’d have to go thru the same initial setup routine I did on the iPhone. Yet, without doing it, the app informed me I’d already subscribed. So why wasn’t all my data there as well? The app itself is far superior to Apple’s own. Unlike theirs, this one is more realistic. For example, taking time off, including daily chores in one’s workout routines. I’m still unsure subscribing is necessary, nonetheless, I’m going thru with it because I believe in supporting those who have gone to the trouble to put such a fine app together. I also commend the developers for tying in Apples exercise data. It takes awhile to download it into the app, but there it all is. Improvements such as enlarging the timer on each exercise routine. For some reason, heart rate is the app’s #1 priority while exercising. Its there in BIG numbers while the timer is stuck in the top left corner in tiny figures. Swimming & not being able to clearly see the elapsed time makes things difficult. Highly recommended for anyone looking for a better exercise app than Apples.

Added Aug 24. Unfortunately, I’ve had to down rate this app due to it’s swimming choices. I did receive a reply regarding the timer, but her advice is wrong. Instead of moving the timer to the middle screen, it starts a separate timer altogether. When finished, swiping to the left to stop takes quite some time cause the watch doesn’t like wet fingers. Then, like EVERY exercise routine in Gentler, it takes a VERY HARD press to get the Done screen to appear. Why so much effort??? But the most egregious error is its failure to call up Apples water eject feature wherein we must spin the crown until hearing an audible sound informing us the watch is unlocked. I’ve no idea if water remains or not.  No matter what I do, that eject water feature just does not appear.

content.text: I read a lot about this app and was excited to try it, but during every day of the free trial it told me I was overworked and to take a rest day. Every day! The fact that I’ve had only rest days for a year kind of scares me — what body metrics is this thing reading and what is wrong with me?? Well, you can’t find out on the app or the website what inputs it’s using to tell you to rest. If it’s just a calibration problem that would be good transparency to put somewhere in the insights. Otherwise this company is simply withholding information rather than stopping me from being overwhelmed by it.

title: Suggestion and Review: Gentler Streak App

content.text: I have recently started using your app and became immediately attached to it! As a D1 athlete, I use my Apple Watch almost every day when it comes to seeing the number of calories I burnt, the distance I traveled, my average pace, and now my recovery meter! I wanted to make a recommendation for one of the activities on the app: Outdoor Rowing. Currently, the watch face only displays my calories burnt, the amount of time that has gone by, and my average heart rate. I would really like it if there was a way to customize it and see my distance as I row. Some additional features such as my pace, or stroke rate would be a great add-on as well. Overall, I'm super satisfied with the app that your team has created!

Old:

content.text: I’ve been using Gentler Streak Premium for about a month, and it’s been a game changer for both my physical fitness and mental health. I now no longer feel guilty for taking a rest day, in fact now I embrace it! Counterintuitively, my cardio fitness (as measured by my VO2 max) and my strength have improved despite taking more days off. I now realize that I was likely doing too much activity and not resting enough. I’m working hard to stay in the green, although I still “overreach” about once a week. So far, I have nothing but good things to say about this app!

content.text: This app’s design does a beautiful job of actually motivating me to be active. You can exercise a little bit every day or a lot every couple days and the app will recognize it as keeping a streak as long as you do enough but not too much. I’ve always felt like the apple watch’s default metric view was too aggressive and doesn’t seem to have any way to really say “hey you’re pushing too hard.” It also has a way to easily compare your activity over different periods of time and set goals for yourself. Very much worth the $20/y

content.text:
I got gentler streak as I thought it would better help me track my fitness and be more understandable than other apps like Aptive 
It tells me my body is struggling and I should take a few days off. 
So I do. 

Then it tells me my fitness is in decline and I need to work out. 
So I do…. 

Halfway through a workout the app is telling me I need to take a break because my body is struggling 🤯

Please make up your mind. 
I’ve been pushing myself at this level of 6 months and have no problem with it. So why does the app think I have a problem?

title: Great way to look at health data

content.text:
I love the way the data is presented in this app. It’s really clear and easy to find and yet includes a lot of information. The layout of this app is excellent and the graphics are great. I love scrolling through and seeing all my workouts in one place and digging deeper to see how I did during those workouts.  

I have always wished Apple had a mechanism for taking a rest day or saying I was sick and taking it easy and this app lets me do that. I love the idea of the activity cloud as a quick way to see how I’m doing. I wonder though, if it adjusts over time because I signed up at a time when I hadn’t been super active for a while and now that I’m going back to my regular routine it thinks I’m working too hard. 

Overall, I’m loving this app and I highly recommend it.

content.cleanHtml: Great app! Looking forward to seeing it expand! Love the layout and the fun information given to match my activity. Keeps me engaged and coming back. Would love a “body battery” kind of meter and maybe expand into sleep tracking in relation to recovery with HRV and RHR. Basically whoop and garmin it up but keep the same charm. Otherwise as is it’s leaps and bounds better than what Apple gives stock and I’d recommend people install this app! Really great job.
